Trichoderma ghanense is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Trichoderma, which is known for its ubiquity in soil and its ability to act as a biological control agent against various plant pathogens. Trichoderma ghanense was first isolated from soil samples collected in Ghana, West Africa, and was subsequently characterized and described as a distinct species.

Morphologically, Trichoderma ghanense is a filamentous fungus that produces green-colored conidia (asexual spores) on branched conidiophores. The colony growth on culture media is typically fast-growing and cottony in appearance. Microscopically, the fungus exhibits the characteristic features of the Trichoderma genus, such as the presence of hyaline, septate hyphae and the production of green, globose to subglobose conidia.

Genetically, Trichoderma ghanense has been identified and differentiated from other Trichoderma species through DNA sequence analysis, particularly of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of the ribosomal DNA (rDNA) and other molecular markers.

Ecologically, Trichoderma ghanense is believed to play a role in the soil ecosystem, where it may contribute to the decomposition of organic matter and the suppression of plant pathogens. Its potential as a biocontrol agent against various plant diseases is an area of ongoing research and exploration.
